item.title: El FBI investigó los vínculos de Epstein con funcionarios de aduanas de EE. UU.
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein cultivó relaciones amistosas con varios funcionarios de aduanas de las Islas Vírgenes de EE. UU. Esos lazos fueron objeto de una investigación criminal.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich and Steve Eder

media:content.media:credit: Gabriella N. Baez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Little St. James, una isla privada propiedad de Jeffrey Epstein en el Caribe.

item.title: How Olympic Experts Keep the Ice Intact
item.description: A team of skilled technicians and drivers keep the frozen surface at the right temperature and thickness. The challenge? Each event needs a different kind of ice.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ice-resurfacing machines known as Zambonis restore the frozen surface of competition before, during and after Winter Olympics competitions.

item.title: La detención del expríncipe Andrés frustra los esfuerzos de la familia real por superar el escándalo
item.description: La investigación sobre el expríncipe podría rivalizar con las bodas reales y las coronaciones como uno de los mayores espectáculos públicos de la historia británica moderna.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

media:content.media:credit: Phil Noble/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, en el centro, hermano del rey Carlos III, tras salir de una comisaría el jueves.

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot Survived Mass Rape. Now She’s Looking to the Future.
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot stayed silent after dozens of men were convicted of raping her. Now, Ms. Pelicot is finding peace by publicizing her ordeal and explaining how she survived it.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.category: A Hymn to Life: Shame Has to Change Sides (Book)

media:content.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Lost Boys’ on Broadway and Cynthia Erivo in ‘Dracula’: Why Vampires Won’t Die
item.description: With “The Lost Boys” on Broadway and Cynthia Erivo in “Dracula” in London, our horror expert looks at how bloodsuckers sunk their teeth into pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Murky Waters’ for Global Businesses After Trump’s Tariff Loss
item.description: Even after the Supreme Court invalidated many of the president’s levies, foreign leaders and executives assume that U.S. tariffs are here to stay, in one form or another.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

media:content.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A denim jeans factory in Dong Nai Province, Vietnam.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Athletes Live on the Edge. Their Parents Teeter on It.
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 21, 2026.

item.title: Big Times
item.description: Josh Knapp’s latest themeless puzzle presents a lot of obstacles to move through.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Carmen Jaspersen/dpa, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A primped show cow on a mission at a beauty pageant in Germany.

item.title: Who Is Not Funding This Antarctic Expedition?
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong describes America’s shifting relationship with polar research amid the threat of rising sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Stephanie Swart and Anna Casper

item.title: Bridge Owner Donated $1 Million to MAGA Group Before Trump Blasted Competitor
item.description: The PAC and the White House say the donation had nothing to do with President Trump’s tirade against a new bridge connecting Detroit and Windsor, Ontario.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

media:content.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Gordie Howe International Bridge under construction in Windsor, Ontario, in January 2024.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 21, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 21, 2026.

item.title: U.S. Kills 3 in Latest Boat Strike
item.description: Legal specialists on the use of lethal force have said the strikes are illegal, extrajudicial killings.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gen. Francis L. Donovan, the leader of the U.S. Southern Command, last month in Washington.

item.title: La declaración de independencia de la Corte Suprema de EE. UU.
item.description: El rechazo de la Corte Suprema al programa arancelario del presidente Trump es el más reciente de una serie de choques entre él y el presidente del tribunal, John Roberts Jr.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente de la corte, John Roberts Jr., redactó el viernes la opinión mayoritaria contra los aranceles del presidente Trump.

item.title: Police Chief Placed Millions in Bets as He Embezzled, Investigators Say
item.description: Karl R. Jacobson was arrested and accused of stealing from city coffers as he placed $4.5 million in online bets. He resigned in January, when the accusations first surfaced.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko

media:content.media:credit: City of New Haven, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: New Haven Police Chief Karl Jacobson is charged with two counts of larceny in the first degree by defrauding a public community, according to the state’s attorney.

item.title: Trump Presses on With Tariffs, Posing Challenge for Republicans
item.description: The president is plowing ahead with an unpopular policy after the Supreme Court’s rebuke, deepening his party’s risk in the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “We have very powerful alternatives,” President Trump declared, announcing a new 10 percent import tax. “For those who thought they had us.”

item.title: Con Men Posing as Lawyers and Judges Preyed on Immigrants, U.S. Says
item.description: Five Colombian citizens were charged with bilking people facing immigration proceedings by staging fake versions of those proceedings.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar

media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Munoz/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Joseph Nocella Jr., the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

item.title: 6 Takeaways From the Supreme Court’s Tariff Decision
item.description: The court displayed its independence in what was a stinging rebuke to President Trump, though the ruling is unlikely to have an immediate effect on prices.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In a landmark ruling, the Supreme Court on Friday invalidated many of the tariffs imposed by President Trump.

item.title: L.G.B.T.Q. Clubs in Some Texas Schools Can’t Be Banned, Judge Says
item.description: A Texas law passed last year was the first in the nation to explicitly ban clubs based on gender identity in K-12 schools. The judge blocked its enforcement in three school districts.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:credit: Kaylee Greenlee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Texas law also prohibits employees at K-12 public and charter schools from “assisting” students with socially transitioning between genders.

item.title: Judge Rebukes U.S. Over Application to Search Washington Post Reporter’s Home
item.description: A prosecutor apologized for failing to alert the magistrate to a 1980 law that restricts searches for reporting materials.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Erik Wemple

media:content.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Eastern District of Virginia courthouse in Alexandria, Va., on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Planes Land at Jordan Base, a Key Hub for Planning Possible Iran Strikes
item.description: At least 60 attack aircraft are parked at the base, which has become a key hub for U.S. military planning for possible strikes on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen, Christoph Koettl and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: With Tariff Changes, Consumers May Be Stuck in a Waiting Game
item.description: Some companies could decide to temper price increases, but the effect would take time to materialize.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Jordyn Holman

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Economists cautioned that the Supreme Court ruling would probably not lower sticker prices right away, if at all.

item.title: Court Clears Way for Louisiana Law Requiring Ten Commandments in Classrooms
item.description: A federal appeals court vacated a temporary block on the 2024 law, tossing a previous decision that called it “plainly unconstitutional.”
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas

media:content.media:credit: Hilary Scheinuk/The Advocate, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Liz Murrill, the Louisiana attorney general, speaks alongside Gov. Jeff Landry during a news conference regarding the state’s Ten Commandments in Baton Rouge, La., in 2024.

item.title: New York Man Tried to Ram a Nevada Power Station in Act of Terrorism, Police Say
item.description: The man, Dawson Maloney, of Albany, was heavily armed during the attack on Thursday in Boulder City, Nev. He died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Rylee Kirk
item.category: Los Angeles Department of Water and Power

media:content.media:credit: Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department
media:content.media:description: Sheriff Kevin McMahill of the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department discussing the crash on Friday.

item.title: 64% of Americans Disapprove of Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The poll found disapproval among men, women, all racial and ethnic groups and across educational backgrounds.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik

media:content.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Port of Seattle in Seattle.

item.title: Ruben Ray Martinez Was Killed in an Undisclosed ICE Shooting in March, His Family Says
item.description: A 23-year-old American was shot last March in South Padre Island. ICE’s involvement in the shooting was not disclosed until this week.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra and Edgar Sandoval

media:content.media:credit: Ronaldo Schemidt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The shooting last March occurred in South Padre Island, Texas.

item.title: Longtime Virginia Lawyer Chosen by Judges as U.S. Attorney, and Then Fired
item.description: It was the second time this month that the administration had gotten rid of a top federal prosecutor appointed to his post by federal judges.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

item.title: How Stephen Miller Is Perceived in the White House
item.description: Stephen Miller is at the “top of the totem pole” in Donald Trump’s White House. On a recent episode of “The Ezra Klein Show,” the Atlantic staff writers Ashley Parker and Michael Scherer describe the scale of Miller’s influence.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: White House Dims Lights as Trump Responds to Tariff Ruling
item.description: The mood lighting appeared to be borrowing from the playbook of former President Joseph R. Biden Jr., and the old meme of “Dark Brandon.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump at a news conference at the White House on Friday. With him were D. John Sauer, the United States solicitor general, left, and Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary.

item.title: How Does Trump Really Spend His Time?
item.description: President Trump is running the White House on “gut instinct” and late-night phone calls, Ashley Parker and Michael Scherer, staff writers for The Atlantic, tell Ezra Klein on a recent episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: The U.S. Tariffs Causing the Most Pain for Canada Remain in Place
item.description: While the vast majority of Canadian exports were exempt from the tariffs now struck down, the ruling does not effect duties harming several key industries.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

media:content.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada toured Algoma Steel last year in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

item.title: Ask The Morning: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: The justices struck down a central piece of President Trump’s agenda. What does that mean?
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning

item.title: How The Times Made Its Tiny, Animated Olympic Athletes
item.description: The Times’s tiny animated athletes flip, spin and soar through the air just like their real-life counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Alice Fang, Matt Ruby, Wilson Andrews and Eden Weingart

media:content.media:credit: Alice Fang, Jon Huang, Matt Ruby, Eden Weingart and Yuhan Liu/The New York Times

item.title: Guillermo del Toro on Writing and Directing the Oscar-Nominated ‘Frankenstein’
item.description: Ahead of this year’s Academy Awards, the director appeared on the Book Review podcast to speak about his latest film.

item.title: Brooklyn Beckham Spices Up Miami Burger Bash With His Own Hot Sauce
item.description: Amid a family spat that has kept his name in headlines, Brooklyn Beckham appeared at a food festival with a hot sauce from his condiment line.
item.dc:creator: Linda Marx
item.category: South Beach Wine and Food Festival

media:content.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brooklyn Beckham, a host of the Burger Bash at this year’s Food Network South Beach Wine & Food Festival, mingled with attendees at the start of the event on Thursday.

item.title: Park Service Workers Reinstall Exhibit on Slavery in Philadelphia
item.description: Plaques on the history of slavery in Philadelphia were reinstalled at the President’s House site after being taken down last month following a Trump administration directive. In a lawsuit by the City of Philadelphia, a federal judge ruled that the exhibit must be temporarily put back up while the case proceeds in court.
item.dc:creator: Christina Kelso

media:content.media:credit: Joe Lamberti/Associated Press

item.title: See the Best Moments From the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics
item.description: See the Winter Olympics in a series of composite images.
item.dc:creator: Weiyi Cai, Bedel Saget, Joe Ward, Jeremy White, Josh Williams, Malika Khurana and Bora Erden

media:content.media:credit: Jeremy White

item.title: A.I. Is Coming for the 2026 Midterms
item.description: Our tech columnist Kevin Roose explains A.I.’s potential impact.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Artificial intelligence companies have an increasingly important role in American politics.

item.title: Trump Promises New Tariffs After Justices Rule Against Him
item.description: Also, Cuba nears collapse. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times

item.title: SPECIAL EPISODE: TRUMP’S TARIFFS STRUCK DOWN
item.description: In a 6-3 decision, the Supreme Court struck down President Trump’s global tariffs, a cornerstone of his second term.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Adam Liptak, Rob Syzpko, Carlos Prieto, Rikki Novetsky, Devon Taylor and Dan Powell

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Supreme Court dealt a major blow to President Trump’s economic policy on Friday, ruling that he had exceeded his authority when he imposed tariffs on nearly every U.S. trading partner.

item.title: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling to Spur Chaotic Refund Process
item.description: The Trump administration says it could take years and additional litigation for importers to get their money back.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith

media:content.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Trump administration may have to refund more than $100 billion in tariff revenue to thousands of American importers.

item.title: John Shirreffs, 80, Dies; Trainer of a Nearly Perfect Horse
item.description: He guided Zenyatta, a spectacular mare, to 19 consecutive wins and won the Kentucky Derby in 2005 with Giacomo, a 50-1 long shot.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

media:content.media:credit: Howard Lipin/San Diego Union-Tribune, via ZUMA Press
media:content.media:description: The horse trainer John Shirreffs walks Zenyatta, his star mare, after her morning workout in Del Mar, Calif., in 2010.

item.title: Supreme Court Rules Against Trump’s Tariff Policy
item.description: In a 6-to-3 decision, the Supreme Court ruled that President Trump exceeded his authority in imposing tariffs on nearly every U.S. trading partner.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump holding a news conference at the White House on Friday. With him, from left, were D. John Sauer, the United States solicitor general; Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary; and Jamieson Greer, the United States trade representative.

item.title: The Save America Act Is an Assault on Democracy
item.description: President Trump would have you think that voter fraud is rampant, says the Opinion columnist Jamelle Bouie. The reality? That’s just not true. So why are Trump and his allies so preoccupied with passing the Save America Act?
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie and Ingrid Holmquist

item.title: Russia Takes the Gulag Out of the Gulag History Museum in Moscow
item.description: The museum had preserved the history of brutality inflicted by the Soviet Union on its people. It will now focus on Nazi war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar

media:content.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An exhibition at the Gulag History Museum in Moscow in 2022. There are plans to turn the space into a Museum of Memory focused on Nazi war crimes.

item.title: Trump tiene una estrategia para mantener los aranceles
item.description: La sentencia de la Corte Suprema es un duro golpe, pero el gobierno de EE. UU. dispone de otras herramientas.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Camiones en marcha atrás en el lado estadounidense del paso fronterizo del Puente del Comercio Mundial, en Laredo, Texas, a finales del año pasado.

item.title: Businesses Celebrate Tariff Relief, And Brace for New Uncertainty
item.description: The Supreme Court’s ruling against many of President Trump’s tariffs cheered executives who set to work seeking refunds on their duties.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember

media:content.media:credit: Jimena Peck for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Travis Campbell, who owns the luggage manufacturer Eagle Creek, said he hoped to recoup over half a million dollars in tariffs.

item.title: Why ‘Wuthering Heights’ Falls Flat
item.description: Wesley Morris, host of “Cannonball,” and Sasha Weiss, the culture editor of The New York Times Magazine, discuss Emerald Fennell’s steamy film adaptation of the novel “Wuthering Heights.”

item.title: Melania Trump Presents Her 2025 Inaugural Gown to the Smithsonian
item.description: The dress joined an exhibit of gowns belonging to first ladies stretching back to Helen Taft in 1909, and Mrs. Trump spoke about how high fashion reflected humanity.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Because President Trump was elected to nonconsecutive terms, Melania Trump will have two gowns in the collection.

item.title: Michael Silverblatt, NPR’s ‘Bookworm’ Who Interviewed Authors, Dies at 73
item.description: His public radio show, “Bookworm,” was a literary salon of the air for 33 years, drawing guests like Joan Didion, Susan Sontag and David Foster Wallace.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

media:content.media:credit: Monica Almeida/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Michael Silverblatt in 1999 while hosting “Bookworm” on KCRW, a public radio station on the campus of Santa Monica College. “The purpose of the show is to help my listeners look through writers’ eyes,” he said.

item.title: ‘A Disgrace’: How Trump Found Out the Supreme Court Ruled Against Him
item.description: The news arrived in a note passed by the U.S. trade representative.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump speaking to governors at the White House on Friday.
